Prerequisite: Freshman Writing Requirement
Course fulfills the Continuing Writing Requirement and the HSC Requirement
Course Description:
How did the American founders draw on the legacy of Greece and Rome?
How did the classical heritage shape American civic and political culture?
The course poses these and related questions in exploring the classical tradition in colonial America and the United States. We will examine texts both ancient and American as well as other evidence, including film and architecture. Throughout the course we will discuss the ways we continue to encounter classical receptions today.
Most readings are available online. They include excerpts from Cicero, Virgil, The Federalist, the writings of Alexander Hamilton, Thomas Jefferson, Phillis Wheatley, and from the Columbian Orator.
Required Book:
Plutarch's Lives. The Dryden Translation, ed. Arthur Hugh Clough, Vol. I and Vol. II (The Modern Library/Random House)
Grading:
Class participation and discussion emphasized; two midterm essays, final paper; quizzes.
course_description: A study of the role of the Greco-Roman legacy during formative decades of the American republic and in shaping civic values in the United States.
